column10: 1) Is the pay livable for this area? 2) Livable but you'll be renting and it would be helpful to have a spouse's salary 3) note requirement about statment of faith 4) What do you consider livable? Is $90K+ for 9 months not a livable wage? 5) according to Payscale.com, cost of living in Malibu is 187% higher than the national average, including housing that is 645% higher than the national average. Median home price is $3,225,692. So, there's that. Of course, you could live in a surrounding area, but it's not like anything in that region is affordable. 6) Probably a silly question, but if I am not involved in a community of faith, is that an automatic dealbreaker? 7) @6 no, they cannot legally discriminate based on religion, though weird get around where they can give some sort of preference to people with shared faith. in practicality you do not want to work at a place like Pepperdine unless you are christian, it would be very isolating 7) @ 4, it's all relative, comparing 90k in that area to my current area would be like make 26k, which I do not classify as livable. 8) Some schools have programs to help new faculty find housing or provide on-campus. Quick search on PU found this: https://www.pepperdine.edu/reo/employee-housing/ Read for details, it still may not be a good deal. 9) @5, if nothing in the region is affordable, then how could faculty (and staff who earn less) work and live there? Pepperdine has affordable employe housing in Malibu and the surrounding neighborhoods are affordable: Santa Monica, Oxnard, Calabasas, Agoura Hills, Thousand Oaks, etc. 10) @7, yes, faith-based universities in the United States can legally discriminate in hiring on the basis of religion. Don't apply if you're not a Christian. 11) as a heads up When I applied in 2020, Pepperdine had a statement of faith on the last screen before submitting that was fairly specific and I was not comfortable signing (as a Christian who has submitted a statement of faith to other institutions).  I felt bad about asking for letters but ultimately didn't apply.  Would probably be worth looking into before putting the time into an application

column10: 1) Says job will take place at "University of Toronto Mississauga: Biology" but that "UTM is part of the tri-campus University of Toronto ecosystem, and all faculty have appointments in the graduate departments of Cell and Systems Biology, or Ecology and Evolutionary Biology.". Does that mean once can choose to be permanenlty situated in the EEB dept? Missisauga and Toronto are two very different things 2) EEB alumnus here, probably not. You will likely be based at UTM and involved in tri-campus service, like sitting on student committees. 3) Note: "This position is an excellent opportunity for individuals working on any organism that does not require the use of animal care facilities" 4)@1, could you expand on the difference between UTM and U of T? 5) U of T is the main, St. George campus downtown in Toronto. UTM is the satellite campus in Mississauga (which is part of the GTA but west of the the downtown). Because Toronto is the worst city in the world, they are about 30 km apart but it takes an hour to drive between them. 6) An hour in good traffic :)  7) UTM has a nice campus and Mississauga is very family-friendly 8) Echoing 7) here. Mississauga is very green and the campus sits on Erindale Park and the Credit River. If you live near a GO train station then it takes no time to get to downtown Toronto. Alternatively, several faculty live in west end Toronto and commute. Salary and start-up are the same across campuses and you're very much a member of the EEB and CSB groups. 9) I grew up in Mississauga - the campus is in a nice place and very family friendly. You can get a pretty decent startup if you advocate for yourself.
We invite applicants whose research leverages modern genomic tools and statistical approaches to address fundamental questions in evolutionary biology.

column10: Seeking a wildlife veterinarian to fill a tenure-track position focused on ocelot recovery and conservation. Successful candidate will oversee the new, state-of-the-art Ocelot Conservation Facility, with the goal of augmenting the wild ocelot population through release of individuals reared at the facility. column4: Conservation and Management of Biological Resources
column10: Applicant must be the author or coauthor of at least 50 articles in the subject area OR have attained at least 500 citations (excluding self-citations) in the area of interest OR must have an H-index of 10 or higher. 1) I somehow appreciate seeing actual target metrics (x1) 2) could this be internal? Often these stupid requirements (50 pubs??) come out when they have someone in mind. 3) haha what a joke! x7 4) jesus, what early career reseacher has 50 publications? 5) I'm like 1% eligible for this position lol 6) I've got about 45, but I'm marginally ECR and I don't have a job either. 7) Eh, I qualify easily and don't have a permanent job and I know several others in the same position. Unfortunately I'm geographically constrained. Strict number limits are obviously dumb, but it's way more common in searches I've seen to hire underqualified than overqualified candidates, so I guess that won't happen in this case. 8) Also, if it is an internal candidate with 50 pubs who needs a permanent job, they should absolutely hire that person anyway! x2 9) @ 4, 8 I have >60 and am still in the ECR bracket without a TT job. There's been a lot of targeted discrimination in academic hiring over the last decade - as 7 points out there's often no way to justify the hires objectively. It's actually nice to see standards here for a change. 8) It says 50 publications which is unreasonable OR 500 citations, which is not hard. Come on, people, learn how to read. Portuguese universities are very inbred and they need these type of calls to remove internal candidates which have managed contract after contract despite accomplishing very little. It is a not the best strategy in the long term, but it is meant to address these cases of inbreeding and "old wood" that is not that old.  9) I think these stats ae basically being very open to applicants that they want definitive productivity demonstrated.  I know MANY people who exceed all of these metrics before exiting a postdoc.  However, MOST people would not hit these numbers until at least a couple of years into an assistant professor position.  The largest majority of people in higher education actually never reach these numbers, ahving been trapped in teaching sweaat shops for too long

Yet having early-career researchers spend many hours preparing detailed application packages, only for those applications to be essentially disregarded, feels completely at odds with those values, and with basic transparency. x1 9) commited to DEI? this is the same department that has repeatedly gifted TT jobs to students of the UBC old guard 10) UofT and UBC are both absolute shit-shows of neopotism and favoritism.11) This got salty fast. 12) @9 what do you mean UBC old guard (13) LOL could they have been any more obvious with the job posting who they are trying to poach? x1

And by definition anyone getting an offer already had a TT job somewhere else so this would have to be better enough to be worth moving. Seems not all that surprising that it would be tricky to fill.

Yes, the anticipated start date should say 8/1/2026 (2 positions to start 8/1/26, and 2 positions to start 8/1/27) 5) is the committee considering recently promoted full professors? 6) uh oh...full professors coming for this job. good luck all 7) @6 - sadly the only way to get a substaintial raise in our field is to get an offer or move ..... 8) Luckily this full prof cant spell promoted or substantial so I think we have a good shot against them 9) @5 Yes, but you must be willing to demote to Assistant Professor without tenure. 9) People need to be a lot kinder around here - there are a lot of good reasons for why a person might want to move...including that this is a stellar department. x5 10) @7 And of course wanderlust. Never forget that seemingly common character flaw. 11) If I was in a department with some of these people I'd want to move, too. Yikes. Let's not hide behind anonymity and be jerks, okay? x4 10) @11 The truth hurts sometimes. 11) how "ecosystem" is everyone reading the job focus as? 12) Massive purges in the Federal Government (EPA, USDA, NOAA) are going to make any academic position, especially those offered at a higher level, more competitive. Just saying. 13) @12 "I'm just telling it like it is" has been used to excuse bad behavior for decades; that's not an actual reubuttal. And I sincerely doubt the "oh, no, full professors are taking all the jobs!" people will themselves decide never to move one day, lest they become hypocrites (PS, this has been debunked many times; see Jeremy Fox's posts in Dynamic Ecology). 14) I posted 12 more as an FYI about senior positions rather than responding to anything in this thread specifically. 15) @11 I know many of the members of this department and I would speculate they want people who are pretty "ecosystem" heavy. I would think biogeochemistry and ecosystem metabolism, cycling of matter and energy, nutrient dynamics, etc. Having a conservation or organismal tie-in might not be a bad idea though because they are land grant and have the Warnell School of Forestry with potential collaborators.

column10: Brazilian here. Great university, one of the best in Latin America. São Paulo has a lot of money for research. Salary is good. But before anyone gets excited, I suggest you investigate the hiring process in Brazil: which insluded writen exams (taken in portuguese IN SÃO PAULO!). Another Brazilian here. Some processes offer the possibility to do the test in English. To be honest, it's a bogus system - they use these tests because they're too lazy to properly review every applicant's CV and research record. Yes, the exam is required by law, but universities are too lazy to confront this requirement and design a more effective process that actually evaluates research merit. At the end, you read your test to the professors evaluating you, and they throw scores as they please to pass the candidates they want - increasing the score here and there for the ones they favor, decreasing for others. Bottom line: after the whole process that involves a 5-hour long test, a mock lecture, an interview... the committee president tries to convince the other members to pick the candidate he wants. The selection is subjective like all selections are, but they include this long test only to make things worse.

column10: Any idea what the teaching load is like here? 2) Department member here: Teaching load is currently a 3/2, but the college is moving to a 2/2 in the next few years. Under the 3/2 model, there is a course reduction for the first year. It’s important to note that class sizes are small, and upper-level labs (200 and 300-level) count as a full course, meaning a lecture and its associated lab together count as two courses. Also, the only course with multiple lab sections is Introductory Biology, and those labs are taught by dedicated faculty members.

column10: "Demonstrated research expertise in terrestrial animal ecology, with a focus on anthropogenic impacts on biodiversity." 1) Anyone have any insight about living in Townsville? 2) TSV is very isolated (~15 drive north of Brisbane, 5hrs south of Cairns), but has it's own charms (beaches, ~11 months of sunshine p/year, some culture, etc..). Very laid back lifestyle. This region has a reputation in Aus for being extremely backwater, so it's hard to recruit domestic PhD students.  It's common that faculty go there because of the reputation of JCU, and then end up staying because they love TSV or Cairns...... not because they like JCU. 3) isn't this the same school that a bunch of infamous fraudsters came from? 2) Bunch? One PhD student, multiple papers. My understanding is that the accused faculty member probably wasn't committing fraud, but used an inappropriate method for several papers, which led to erroneous results. Both people were in the Marine Bio department, not the Zoology and Ecology dept which is advertizing here. 4) looks like there's two high profile cases of fraud from former JCU grads: https://ipa.org.au/ipa-today/time-for-jcu-to-accept-it-has-a-problem-with-research  5) What is the teaching/research expectation? It's listed as lecturer, but the description sounds like both are expected? 6) Lecturers in Australia are equivalent to Assistant Professors in the US. Commonly, lecturers have a balanced portfolio of 40% research, 40% teaching, and 20% service. 2) It's hard to say exactly what the teaching load is, as it's based on a complex model worked out by the former dept. VC and the union, and the rules of the contract are routinely ignored. When I started, teaching load was 2-3 classes a year, normally during the same semester (leaving the other semester for fieldwork). Now, I think it's closer to 4 classes with trimesters. The research expectations are decently high. This is a productive department with lots of good researchers.
Is this position open to PhD related to toxicology (as it relates to environmental hazards)?

"molecular and cellular biology" + no mention of ecology or evolution = not ecoevojob 2) "molecular genetics as a broadly defined field" -- this encompasses molecular evolution & evolutionary genetics. 3) I'd say this is definitely relevant here since you may have molecular ecologists/evo geneticists interested in this type of work 4) So is there any molecular/cellular biology job that we shouldn't include? 5) plenty of bio-med/physiology-focused mol biol jobs don't belong here, but the "broadly defined" jobs like this absolutely fit 6) The teaching specifies genetics and upper-levels determined by the candidate. Some on here certainly be able to teach genetics but many probably not as comfortable with that as an eco/evo course. Would be nice to know if the SC wants an upper-level molecular course or if an evo course woudl be ok as well. 7) Given that a lot of positions are cancelled/withdrawn, it would serve the community here to be more inclusive in posting more diverse positions that may even be of slight interest to folks here. 8) As an evolutionary biologist with experience in genetics, it is very useful to see these sorts of jobs here. I certainly don't see any harm in these sorts of postings. x2 6 again) My only concern is that ads like this are ambiguous in terms of preferences. It could be that the SC is open to all kinds of genetics folks or it could be that they are really looking for a cell/molec person but casting a wide net. Teaching expectations or clarity about research program would be useful and could save many of us time/effort if the department really wants someone on the 'other' side. These ads draw tons of applicants who are trained in MCB programs and can lead evo types to be dismissed out of hand. 8 again) 7 hit it spot on, a lot of us are looking at positions that may even be of slight interest, and benefit from more diverse positions here given the current environment in the US especially. Nobody is forcing anyone to apply to the jobs listed here, and it is lame that some positions need more clarity, but it is certainly not hurting anyboding just to post things here. ***9) Hi! I posted this and am loosely involved in the search and work in the dept. I'm an eco person myself, and know a lot of eco/evo people who do genetics that could easily handle an intro class and have interesting upper-levels to share at the cell/molec scale that are not biomedical. Honestly, I'd be happy to see more applicants that span topics beyond biomed applications (yeast evolution! disease pathways in non-model systems, etc). That said, I am not chairing the search, but wanted the job ad to be widely viewed in a space like this because not all people who work in genetics are coming out of MCB PhD/post-docs. ALSO, to address the upper-level classes, I would think preference is towards classes that touch on molec/cell, but for instance, that could still be in eco/evo world too - for instance, we have a biogeographer/entomologist, but not a population geneticist, etc etc. 10) @9 Are you open to bacteria people who do genetics? 11) I think if you can teach courses related to genetics you are a good fit to be an applicant. The species/model of interest is secondary to the ability to teach genetics. Please refer to job ad for detail!

column10: [link fixed -AP] 1) focus on aquatic systems 2) They are looking for ecological aspects, less behavioral, and not just aquatic, also terrestrial is fine for them 3) Note that it says at the bottom of the posting: "Unfortunately, travel and accommodation expenses incurred in connection with the admission procedure cannot be reimbursed."

"ORGANISMAL ECOLOGISTS whose research has a significant field component and who uses quantitative and/or computational modeling approaches to answer critical questions in ecology" 1) Anybody know who the search chair is? I am interested but don't know what exactly they are looking for with this combo of skills. 2) The wording was a little funny in the listing. Would the lab just be for Masters or PhDs too? I thought Villanova was a R2 school 3) Villanova's bio department has a terminal master's program but not a PhD program. 4) "For finalists, an official graduate transcript will be required and a reflection on the Mission of the University." How deeply is this reflection tied to the religious affiliation of the school? Any concept on the strength of religious befliefs in teaching and culture? 5) @4 FWIW: I was a grad student there in the late aughts and at least at that time, there was no strong connection between religious belief and teaching or research. Heck, the science building is Mendel Hall, as in the Augustinian monk and "father" of genetics Gregor Mendel. From my perspective, there was a deep respect for science and little, if any, direct connection (really none at all from my perspective) between religion and the functioning of the department. 6) I also was a grad student there around 10 years ago and I can second what 5 is saying. That said, I think a lot of the student body identifies as Catholic and there are crucifixes in every room lol 7) Went here as an undergrad (many years ago now) and it never felt like a "religious" school. Theology, ethics, and philosophy are required classes for all students, but weren't exclusively catholic. Biology classes were just as secular as non-religious schools. Honestly, fewer anti-abortion protestors on campus compared to the public R1 I attended for grad school. 8) I am confused about the definition of organismal ecologists--is this wording used to specifically exclude population and community elements to the study of organisms? confused because of the juxtaposition of organismal ecology with quantitative/computational components... 9) note that in the listing it says review starts Sept 2 but closing date is Sept 5; 10) SC member here: Answering a few questions: The job ad is specifically broad as we want to find the best candidate for our department. We are looking for someone who can combine ecological/computational expertise - organismal does not exclude pop or community but more focuses on multicellular organisms/communities. We are an R2 with a terminal master's in Biology. We will begin reviewing applications on Sept 2nd. VU while a catholic school does not dictate what we teach or how we run our classrooms/research labs. The reflection on the mission does not need to be religiously focused and should rather highlight how you can move the mission of the university forward with your teaching and research program. 11) That's super helpful 10, thank you! x2

column10: Individuals from underrepresented groups are encouraged to apply ... for $50K per year. 1) Salary is pitiful, even compared to most post-docs, but note that only a MS is required 2) Are we really going to debate whether it's somehow bad for a position that only requires an MSc to pay less than a typical postdoc? 3) It lists PhD as preferred and I would be shocked if they interview anyone with only an MS. 4) I might be less shocked given the salary. Anecdotally, I'm hearing of more failed searches for low-budget position due to poor applicant pools this year. So, might be a great opportunity for a recent MS grad who knows they want to teach 5) I don't agree that $50K is a great opportunity for someone with a Master's degree. Are our expectations really that low? 6) I don't think academics truly understand how underpaid we are, despite that many of us think we do. My partner recently landed a tech job straight out of phd that pays not double not triple but quadrupedal their phd salary (a little more than that actually). Given that my skillset is not too dissimilar, it has entirely re-framed the kinds of positions I will even consider moving forward. 50k isn't worth clicking on the link if you have a phd, even given the location. 7) @6 seems to be projecting their own experience on all of academia....A lot of academics are well aware, and still prefer to earn less and work in academia. If you don't feel that way there is no point in playing the hypercompetitive academic job market while juggling 1-3 year postdoc gigs. Just find a job elsewhere like the majority og PhDs do... 8) I don't know any academics that prefer to earn less. Yes, some are willing to accept less because they prefer to work in academia. In general I agree with 6 though, PhDs should demand more.

So close 5) It is amazing how some eco/evo biologists don't realize how much bigger applied fields like vet science and ag science are than our little corner of the ivory tower. A bunch of Depts. of Natural Resources in Western states have entire programs to track and manage elk hoof disease... x2. 6) SCM - not targeted for a specific person; here's a BRIEF DESCRIPTION – Washington State University’s College of Veterinary Medicine seeks a full-time (12 month) tenure-track Associate or Full Professor in the Department of Veterinary Microbiology and Pathology (VMP) to focus on elk hoof disease as part of a program studying infectious diseases of wildlife and diseases that occur at the wildlife-domestic animal interface. Since 2017, WSU has led research into elk hoof disease since the Washington State Legislature provided generous operating funding and a mandate to monitor and assess causes of and potential solutions for the disease. More information on WSU’s research and outreach on elk hoof disease is available at: https://vetmed.wsu.edu/departments/veterinary-microbiology-and-pathology/elk-hoof-disease/ - @5 just let us make jokes from our little corner of the ivory tower we have so little joy left x2 7) There's an epidemic of overly-tailored job ads. In the cover letter section it states you need to provide "iv) a clear statement of status as a Canadian citizen or permanent resident." Does this mean the position is limited to those two groups? 1) further down in the job ad it says "All qualified candidates are encouraged to apply; however, preference will be given to Canadian citizens and permanent residents." So not required but preferred. 2) I think they are required to ask this by law 3) @2 is right, they are also required to hire canadian citizens if two candidates are equally good. There are workarounds and for a PI position it is usually not an issue. But in the public sector it is hell unless you are hired as a postdoc and can get a "LMIA-exempt" work visa 4) Required in Canada, and some places take it more seriously than others. I recently applied for a job in Canada where they determined that there were sufficient qualified Canadians that applied, so all international applicants were rejected at the first stage (I have no problem with this, and they were transparent about it). 5) Some Canadian universities provide a template for this in their job ads; they literally just want a sentence in your cover letter that either says "I am a citizen/permanent resident of Canada" or "I am not a citizen/permanent resident of Canada." It's impossible to know based on your work history, current location, education, etc., and they need to know to execute the preference requirement mentioned above.

Unbelievable.  In this current political and economic light, the last thing I would do is turn down a TT job at a a B10 school.  I realize UNL isn't top of the big 10 elites, but it is a land grant university with absurd resources.  I don't qualify for this kind of position, but the TT market is not going to improve for half a decade at minimum, and insect systematics isn't exactly a growth area of entomology.  7) Maybe all of them had better offers? Sounds unbelievable but seems like the only possible reason? 8) based on the notes section in the previous post, it seems at least one person had another offer. 1 again) Does anyone know who the search chair or who is on the search committee? I had previously applied and got a rejection (I work on insect evolutinary genetics, so might have been too much of a stretch), and wanted to talk to them to see if it's worth applying again! 9) I am one of those people who turned it down, accepted a position outside of the US. 10) @9 very visionary x5 11) UNL is very good about spousal accomodations, those with two body problems should definitely consider applying  12) I was really impressed when I visited UNL recently, including with the grad program.  @1) I suspect it is an early/mid career faculty. Justin ran the last search for Field Crop Entomology. So, unless he is trying to get more service, I doubt it is him. This is probably a replacement for Lance Meinke, who was historically teaching insect identification. If you want to know without biasing your application, I'd reach out to an HR person (Jodi Mackin) and see if they can tell you anything about who the chair is, and if they will talk to you. 13) I'm one of the candidates who has accepted another position - mine is in the US. I wanted to say how positively impressed I was by the collegial and welcoming atmosphere of the department during my visit. Also, the opportunity to interact/collaborate to Morrill Hall makes it even nicer. My decision ultimately came down to location/specific support structures available for graduate students in the program. Happy to elaborate further if helpful. 14) rejection 24 July

column10: Part time 0.5 FTE 3-year term position with the possibility of renewal subject to availability of funds and work performance. 1) Is this normal? It feels like UBC is offering half the salary for the 0.5 FTE role which works out to ~ 35-40k yearly before tax, which doesn't seem liveable unless the lecturer assumes other positions on the side. 2) This is at the UBC satellite campus in Kelowna BC. Not a liveable wage in that area (definitely wouldn't be liveable at their main campus in Vancouver). 3) I wonder if this is for an internal hire? Kelowna is nice, but pretty high cost of living. 4) Kelowna is an exceptionally nice place to live, with outside-of-work-life offering spectacular nature and outdoor opportunities. I agree the salary is extremely low but could always apply and if you get the job maybe argue for a higher wage that at least matches the costs of living in Kelowna? 5) I could see if this was a year contract, expecting someone to work for half a wage for three years is absurd. If someone on the hiring committee sees this, or someone who may have some insight - I'd love to know if there are other mechanisms for gaining a livable wage that isn't disclosed in the posting.

1) I would not recommend working in this department at all. Many faculty are known for having toxic behaviors towards their own students and other lab members. During seminars, they will prefer to belittle the student standing in front as a way of showing that "they know more than the colleague supervising the student". The saddest part is that the department head sees all these behaviors on a daily basis and does nothing about it. 2) I don't agree with the previous opinion. I did my graduate studies in this department. From a student's perspective, the faculty there wants their people to succeed. Half of my peers land on faculty positions in the US, and the rest all find good positions, some in the USDA and others in industry.

column10: This salary is absurd. Also, the job is already listed further down the sheet and it looks like people have been invited for zoom interviews.  AP) New link, so maybe it's repoened? 2) Seems unlikely since someone reported getting a zoom invite just on 4/26. 3) @1 I hate to disappoint you...but that is that is pretty standard non-R1 salary x2 4) no it really isn't. It's lower than a lot of postdocs. x9 5) That's a standard starting assistant professor salary for a Catholic school in the region. 6) catholic schools always have lower pay, but this is bad even by their standards. x2 7) While the salary could be considered low by many reasonable standards, this is far above the median household income in Buffalo. For much of Upstate NY this enables a comfortable lifestyle. 8) "The region is so poor that this is still a good salary" is a terrible trap to fall into. This is low, full stop. 9) Corollary: "this city is so rich that this is a poor salary" is also a terrible trap. Cost of living considerations are either relevant, or they're not. They can't be relevant in wealthy/expensive regions but not relevant in poor/cheap regions. x2 10) As a person who currently lives in Buffalo, this is a bit higher than my pay but still not enough to live on unless you have roommates and a tight budget. 11) As someone who has lived in upstate New York in cheaper places than Buffalo, it's still a low salary. Not to mention postdocs at other institutions in Buffalo itself are still making more than this. 12) Maybe that was a salary someone could live on eight years ago, before housing prices roughly doubled. But low salaries are unfortunately common, particularly if you're talking about smaller, regional colleges. Property taxes are also fairly high in this region. 9) It's still only $10-15k above the minimum living wage for Erie County, which tbh does not feel like a great cushion for the ups and downs of life at this stage (i.e., anyone who wants to save for retirement/buy a car or house/start a family...) https://livingwage.mit.edu/counties/36029 13) They should be embarrased advertising with a salary range this low. 14) Y'all! If this salary as listed does not meet your personal standards, then don't apply! It's more than I'm making as a postdoc in a more expensive area in the Northeast and I'd be really pleased to be in Buffalo with this position. 12) I once thought along those lines, but now I want asst. profs to be compensated decently. 14) Yep, I want that too. Let's hope there are incremental raises. 15) In the past decade there have been only two very modest "cost-of-living" raises (1.5% & 2.5%) at this institution, with any sort of raises being the first thing cut from every budget. Count on this salary being what you make until tenure & promotion.

column10: The successful applicant will have expertise in and experience of conservation biology and field ecology or habitat management. Familiarity with RStudio for teaching of undergraduate statistical analysis is essential. 1) LOL, always read the fine print (including grammatical errors, I note): "Please be aware that should you be shortlisted for a vacant position and invited to attend an interview you will not re-imbursed you for any expenses incurred to attend the interview". This is in the 'How to Apply' document included as a companion in the application process. Non-UK folks, beware. 2) What?! Is this really a thing!? If so, would they expect you to come or would they be OK with a Zoom interview? 1) No idea! Honestly, I've been reading a lot of job ads in the last few years (still haven't gotten that position...) and this one strikes me as a bit....toxic workplacey? Like, when you go in and read the documents they are quite specific and demanding in their expections compared to a lot of other postings, even going so far as to require certifications to teach (or commitment to getting them - maybe this is a thing in UK universities?). The university itself, when you google it, is proud of their ranking towards 'reducing inequalities' but then doesn't cover expenses to interview, functionally limiting candidates to already wealthy or well-off postdocs/profs (unless all interviews are being done solely on Zoom)? I mean, it's a lot coming from a uni that consistently ranks close to or in the lower 20th percentile in the UK. I was excited to see it at first but digging into it I'm considerable less so, and won't be applying anyways because I just straight up can't afford to fund a trip there. It's a bit of a weird job ad, honestly! I'd encourage folks thinking about this one to really dig in to the application materials and judge for themselves. 3) There's a related discussion under General Discussion, apparently it's not that uncommon for European universities not to cover travel costs for interviews... but usually they allow doing it via Zoom. Also the interview itself might in some cases be in the form of a symposium of all candidates presenting on the same day. 4) @3 I have to say it is uncommon, I have done 7 interviews in Europe and never paid anything myself x2 5) It's absolutely not unusual for UK positions to come with the expectation that the candidate will get a formal teaching certification when they start. Frankly, if this surprises you, you must never have heard of the TEF before, or read many person specs for UK jobs... I've never not been reimbursed for an interview in Europe where in-person attendance was expected. I'd almost be willing to bet that they don't have the budget.

column10: LOL "ERC Starting Grant, ERC Consolidator Grant obtained" 2) LOL indeed - seems like a targeted ad IMO. 3) I've seen notes on German universities' sites before that they'll take on people with ERC grants, but stating it as a requirement for an tenure track position is wild. 4) Targetted, but very common practice. At a UK university (research fellow) here, universities in the UK (and likely EU) often provide proleptic offers, meaning they will hire you AFTER your ERC starting grant (or other long fellowship award). 5) Definitely an expectation at some places. I know of cases where one ERC award was not enough to keep a job. 6) yes, it is targeted as someone there recently got the ERC - but it is common practice for austrian universities to offer tenure-track positions to scientists with big ERC grants. 7) yep, targeted. also notice the very short notice. note that it is often not possible for non-tenured local fellows/PIs to write a local ERC grant, as the university laws do not allow stays longer than 8 years in total - so people find an ersatz-university to host an ERC grant, and then negotiate a return (without ever leaving). It's bizzare as they could plausibly get somebody (even) more qualified but they do not even try.

Women only. 1) as a woman, the "women only" makes me a little nervous.... 2) These kinds of posts are always hard to grasp for people living in America, where explicit discrimination like this is illegal. I wonder how many US progressives would support the legalization of women-only positions in the USA 3). It's in Japan, where they are finally trying to do the proactive recruitment to counter very male dominated departments, and sometimes affirmative action is nesessary to start a more organic change. Also Japan operates in a very different way to the West, OIST has a "department of spouses" where the spouses of recruited foreigners will get a job, even if they don't really work on relevant topics..... 4) For reference, <10% of tenured professors in japan are women, and japan consistently ranks as one of the most sexist amongst developed nations. It's not fair to say this is discrimination, its proactive recruitment like 3 is saying. 5) Any information about the hiring process in Hokkaido Univ./Japan?

1) Their previous search failed. Bear in mind that many faculty have left or are in the process of leaving. The related ecology majors have also failed to attract more than ten students in the last few years. They are failing to retain their best students, postdocs and professors. 2) can you elaborate on why you think that is? x2 3) Every time Hong Kong appears on this list, someone makes a post like 1. Last time I recall, it was because the department building itself was a health hazard. Most likely propaganda. 4) What is the salary at the Associate level? 1) it's not propaganda (x3), I currently work here but will be leaving this year. The causes are two-fold. Firstly the city has changed a lot and is not as appealing as it once was to live. Secondly, there is no leadership in the department, all the most senior people are bio-chemists and none of them care about ecology. In the last five years at least 3 new hires have left within two years of joining. Three senior professors have retired. They have only managed to recruit one person recently who hasn't actually joined yet. A handful of assistant and associate profs are also applying elsewhere currently. 1) @ 4 The salary at Associate level would be very competitive. Likely higher than any USA or European institution and also with much lower tax (~15%). x2 5) Formerly associated with this department. It is not unfair to say that it is a mess, although there are good people there. Ecology and Biodiversity are viewed by the leadership as lesser than biochemistry/molecular biology/medical research. This mentality pervades grant assessment panels as well, with the exception of a few funding agencies (e.g., the ECF). Anecdotes of staff members leaving this department, or joining it while spending a substantial amount of time outside of Hong Kong, are not propaganda. 5) @1, we may have crossed paths. All the best in your new endeavours! 5). Just adding here- the previous search did not fail, it's just that so many people are leaving that they cannot keep up- it's literally a revolving door. As someone else noted- of the 4 people hired between Nov 21 and Sept 22 - 3 have left or are leaving, as well as other tenured faculty. 2 more positions have just been offered, but so many people have left so the department is shrinking. Also important to note- none of the candidates interviewed last time were women, and women get less space and less startup. -also whoever said that the building was a heath hazard was propaganda has no idea- it is a health hazard for the people in the office next to the badly ventilated Autoclave room who are now on anti-allergy meds as they regularly get sick when they don't work from home due to the fumes (allergies from autoclave fumes have been recorded since the 1980s), alternate space impossible to access. 6) I was an Associate Professor at another uni in HK until recently. the annual salary including allowance was 1,320,000HKD. Yes, the salary was very good, but that didn't help to make me stay in HK. HK has become a difficult place to live and work nowadays, maybe more difficult than mainland China. And it's so expensive to live that it's very difficult to lure good postdocs and phd students. 7) Are interviews conducted on a rolling basis, or all after the June 30 deadline? 5). Back to @ 6 - yeah I used to work in mainland, it was better than working in HK, I did consider returning when I decided I needed to move on. @ 7, no, last time it took almost a year before they did anything and some people shortlisted already had jobs by then, all the interviews were late Dec- Jan from an August deadline, which was open for maybe 7 months. FYI from the comments above, there is now a corridor that stinks of manure (and adjacent labs) because students run experiments with multiple masks on in the evenings and as ventilation is poor and windows don't open the whole place fills with the smells- seriously a terrible place to work.

Update 5 June 2025: 
I can personally confirm that some of what has been stated above is true. BUT, we have had a change in leadership and are already fixing these issues. I have taken up the role of Associate Director of the Area of Ecology & Biodiversity (https://www.scifac.hku.hk/people/russell-bayden) from this month and am making some big (and positive) changes. I am building on the fantastic team of academics that we already have to get back to being a collegial and productive group - I've already had good feedback from the current academic staff this week! I intend to use these two open positions to add expertise to that team. 

I can confirm some relevant details: 
1. applications close 30 June 2025 - apply now! We will start shortlisting and interviewing soon after that.
2. the salaries are extremely good on a global basis and tax low. There is also an extra housing allowance on top of salary - yes, housing is expensive, but no longer different to other major cities in comparison to the salary (e.g., London, NY, Sydney).
3. Success in research funding in our group is EXTREMELY high. The opportunities for funding here are the best I've seen in the world (the NSF/ARC/NERC equivalent has success rates of ~30%, E&B is generally ~50%).

I am genuinely looking to grow a positive academic environment and so am very keen to have some great people apply!

Any insights as to what they may be looking for? 1) someone to run the department 2) Are they they expecting the candidate to come from an R1? In other words, do they want a research superstar who will also run the department? Hello - I'm a grad in the department and from my understanding, they want someone of full professor rank or up for promotion to that status. 1) As department chair, yes you basically run the department. You would be the voice to the college and university on behalf of the department, have to be the point of contact for the department and mediate conflict. You are a part of managing/understanding departmental funds, etc. 2) I don't think you necessarily need to be from an R1 institution, but I do think they prefer R1 "caliber" of research. 3) It seems like the absolute perfect person would have a strong academic record AND teaching record with organizational and management skills. So, I would say they WANT a superstar, but is that realistic, meh. The department is also very invested in DEI efforts, so if you choose to apply, really emphasize your experiences working with a diverse set of folks, breaking down barriers in STEM, bringing research opportunities into your teaching and outreach, etc. On behalf of the committee, if you meet the minimum qualifications and are interested, we encourage you to apply.  If you have questions regarding this posting, please reach out to the chair of the search committee, Anne Dunn @ anne.dunn@oregonstate.edu.  I hope to see your application soon. Thanks! Kim - search admin 4) Any updates or decisions? 5) Anyone have updates? Heard that they created a short list? Standalone homes certainly exist in DC, but like many high density cities, many people (most even) raise their families in condos or apartments. Like a rural location, it is appropriate to think about whether this is a lifestyle you like or not (from a DC native) 6) From another DC native- most people commute to the city. It is very expensive to live there but there is decent public transport and nice suburbs in VA and MD with great schools and more affordable housing. 7) will they consider folks with a computational biology background, that may only tangentially be involved in biomedical research or is a strong biomedical research program a hard requirement? 8) to 7, this is a repeat of a search from 2023-4 that failed because the candidates were not deemed to be biomedical enough 9) search committee memember here. to 7, a strong biomedical research program is not a hard requirement, as long as the research program thas the potential to be applicable to an NIH grant, that is good enough. to 8 the failed search is not because of "not biomedical enough". 10) @2 I am currently a post-doc in the DC area, I get paid a little over $88k and it is enough to budget my life while still saving some, that being said I choose to live in an MD suburb to save money and I have no dependents. Application form in French. Job announcement too. 1) There are multiple discussions on the French language in Québec below and in "General Discussion". Without repeating too much: French is the only official language in Québec and outside Montréal, everyday life is in French. Yes, people speak english, yes, we can communciate with you if run out of words. There are many anglophones in and outside Montréal but at UQTR you should expect to experience a push towards full communication, not just teaching in French. It is just how it is here. Not defending it but people need to be prepared. The job ad says "Sufficient knowledge of the French language or be determined to learn it once in post. UQTR offers support for learning the French language" 2) i can't access the offer page, as i am "blocked by their security service". I am based in Asia, maybe that's why. "Expected to work closely with Professor Tomomichi Fujita on evolutionary development and/or environmental responses of plants, for example, by using Physcomitrium patens" 1) Japanese-language proficiency is not required 2) Note that in Japan, Assistant Profs. typically work FOR a full prof and have very limited independence relative to the US. 3) even if Japanese is not required for work, it is literally impossible to LIVE in Japan without being able to speak/read/write Japanese to some extent - English (almost) never works in ordinary life. 4) I think it's easier to simply live in Japan with poor Japanese skills than actually work at a University as a PI without those skills. But things are slowly changing and departments are trying to recruit more internationally these days.

column10: 1) 24 contact hours per year!?!?! how the heck is any research supposed to get done, no way. 2) This is a teaching position as stated in the ad, and there are no research responsibilites listed. 3) except "This position will mentor master students in functional genomics research programs and teach courses related to this program" seems like research to me! 4) faculty at another USHE school here. research is expected for sure "maintaining high-quality teaching while also supporting research involving highly motivated undergraduates" and the 24 credits a year is no joke. also, Utah eliminated tenure statewide and the state legislature is cutting educational funding. run. away. 5) Utah absolutely has not eliminated tenure statewide, and it is not on the table in the recently introduced legislation. BTW, I am ACTUALLY faculty at another USHE, and I have no idea about teaching and research requirements at other institutions. I don't think 4 does either. 6) tenure has not been elimated but the tenure process has been revised so that authority moves from faculty to the president and there is now a post-tenure review every 5 years that resembles the tenure process https://le.utah.gov/~2024/bills/static/HB0438.html 7) So they're still calling it "tenure" but it's really that you have to earn tenure repeatedly (every 5 years)!? Cool.

column10: Bellevue College is the largest community college in Wa State, the Life Science faculty are a collaborative group, focused on equity and supporting students. Position with work closely with Environmental Science Faculty. BC has a stong union and salary, class sizes, course load are union negotiated. I am on SC and can answer questions. 1) Is an H1B visa sponsorship available for this position? 2) Is Bellevue College on the quarter system? How would the teaching load be spread out over quarters (or semesters)? OP) re: 1) We have recently done H1B visa sponsorship for new faculty, I'm confirming that with the program chair. OP re 2) We are on the quarter, Lab and lecture courses are weighted slightly differently, the person in this position now teaches seven courses with labs a year 2,3,2. Where each lab course is capped at 28 students. There are opportunities to take on more teaching for additional salary, as well as paid professional development. 3) thank you, OP! Please, let us know about the visa. 4) is there any opportunity/interest from others in the department for research along with teaching? OP re: 4) Some faculty have course based research projects, or do education research.  However, there's not a lot of institutional support or resources for research because our mission is teaching focused. If you're passionate about research being a substantial part of your work a community college is unlikely to be a great fit. 5) Rejection email 5/8.

Anyone know what the typical teaching load is? 2) I'd make a joke about it only being open to internal hires, but I'm not sure the wiki can take it right now. 3) 70k is terrible considering the cost of living in Flagstaff. 4) Flagstaff is expensive! 70K is not great at all [link fixed -AP] 5) Does anyone know if they university provides subsided housing or any help with housing with that salary? Location is great for Wildlife but 70k is tough to justify. 6) second hand but I've heard they do not 7. Anyone know the expected teaching load vs research? 7) I work at NAU in a different department, and live in Flagstaff- they don't subsidize housing. 70k is probably the 9 month salary so with summer salary the upper range of what you could make in a year is ~$87-93k, which is very doable (although the 9-month is doable too - there is a great quality of life here). The new administration has been great at giving raises too, so I would apply if the job description fits. Teaching load depends on specific needs - but 1 lecture and lab per semester, maybe an additional lecture one semester, is about average for research faculty. It's a good amount of teaching. I happen to know this spot is replacing a longtime faculty who recently retired, and there are nice zoology classrooms and a small museum associated with these programs listed in the job. I think it's probably a pretty sweet gig. 8) If someone starts at 70k as an Assistant Professor what would they potentially be able to make for a 9-month salary as an Associate Professor after receiving tenure? 9) Who in wildlife biology is consistently maxing out their 'potential' summer salary? 10) Salaries are public and you can look them up. It looks like Assoc Profs are around low to mid 80s and full are low to mid 90s. Recent assistants do indeed seem to be at 70 or lower to start. 7 again) yes biology has struggled to keep up - many ecologists at NAU work in the Informatics school, which houses the computer science programs, and make CS money which is much better. 11) Jeez, I used to live in Flag as an impoverished grad student so never bothered knowing how much houses cost. I just looked now, and they are startlingly high! 12) No research or teaching statements being required? Just a cover letter and CV? Anyone from SC able to clarify? 13) Does anyone know if there's a taxonomic preference? 14) Not SC member, but faculty in the Bio Dept: Yes, NAU only wants a cover letter and CV; no statements. I'm not sure if there is an official taxonomic preference, but a mammalogist or ornithologist would be an especially good fit. 15) Any updates on this search? x5 16) Invited for zoom interview 3/12 X3 17) Anyone get a campus invite? 18) Campus invites have been sent

column4: Biodiversity and Functional Ecology of Cryptogams
column10: OP: This is a senior scientist position with a initial 6-year fixed-term contract, which can then roll over to a permanent position upon completion of a tenure-track contract. Position is comparable to TT facutly jobs at our Uni but with about 15% lower gross salary, and only half the teaching load. 2) Any opinions on life in Graz as a non-German speaker? My impression is that Austria is a relatively conservative country. 3) generally yes but Graz has a communist mayor. 4) to 2) Ausländer in Graz here. Yes, compared to other countries in Europe its conservative, and to 3) there is little a communist mayor can do against both FPÖ-lead national AND federal governments. Also, seems to be one of those positions with a name already on it. 5) OP here - for context, this is a position to replace a retiring senior scientist, who supported teaching, research, and curation of cryptogams, which is a central focus of our institute. So, yes, topic is a bit niche, but the position is not written with a specific internal candidate in mind, and there will definitely be a competitive selection process. Regarding German, yes, sufficient German to teach (among other things, classes for Lehramt students who will go on to be high school biology teachers) and participate in local broader impact initiatives is required. Regarding politics, yes, a far-right party (FPÖ) looks likely to lead both federal and state governments, so YMMV, though in terms of, e.g., LGBT+ rights, abortion access, social/health services, affordable housing, union activities, etc., the country/state still ranks among the highest in Europe, which is unlikely to change any time soon. Feel free to reach out with any quesitons (adamclarktheecologist.com). (6) I am an American living in Austria and working as a postdoc, and I don't recommend upending your entire life to move to Europe/Austria and especially not to a non-capital city like Graz. It is pretty difficult to integrate here, takes a long time to learn German (I put effort into it!), and TBH Graz is not a great place as far as transportation goes. There will be no convenient way to fly out of Austria to visit family, friends, go to conferences, et cetera. (7) Graz as a city and the University are great places to be. The political situation there is getting a bit tense, as in many places of the world. 8) Deadline extended until February the 27th [updated -AP]

column10: The candidate should have command of a Scandinavian language 2) If it's under the "should" list then it's not required but optional depending on whether the SC wants to emphasize that. The actual requirement (usually poorly enforced) is "Foreign language speakers are expected to be able to teach in a Scandinavian language within three years after being hired." 3) I did a postdoc here a few years ago. Very sleepy museum - everyone is on their own corner, little discussion, very few common interest in collaborating and pursuing larger projects (now they finally have a series of talks (so they may be modernizing), colleagues are friendly but they weren't very supportive. 4) Herps are in the fish collection and very few are catalogued... So I'm guessing reptiles and amphibians are not a high priority there. 5) I did my PhD here (finished 4 years ago). Oslo is a fun city. The museum is sleepy and not a very ambitious place (as mentioned by @3), but it is a good place to work if you value work/life balance and if you see yourself having a modest lab with 2-3 people. I texted the HoD who wrote back to me: "It’s a very open recruitment. My challenge will be to get a super objective assessment of the candidates". So do not be discouraged from applying. 6) I e-mailed HR - 61 applicants for this job, and from my knowledge including some very established faculty. It'll be a loooong process. 7) Any idea of the time line? 6) From my experience with this museum, and seeing 61 applicants, it'll ake them ~6 months to get expert reports and form an internal committee. Expect interviews around September or October.

The methodological focus of this position is on integrative spatial modelling of land-use systems and landscapes, as well as on decision support for sustainable landscape management. 1) What's the work situation for US nationals? 2) What app materials are expected in Switzerland? It says "letter (is this a cover letter or research statement?), diploma (like actual diploma or transcripts?), certificate/reference (what's this?), additional documents (anything standard? is this the research statement?). 3) US natitionals would be fine to apply. You would get a 1 year B permit that you need to renew then after a few years you should get permanent residency. But you would need to show committment to learning a national language in your cover letter for a place like WSL. Email Michelle in HR for the application material questions but the letter is going to be a cover letter, the diploma means a scan of your PhD certificate (not transcripts), reference is unusual that might be a written reference if you have one (note it is not manditory), and additional docs would be where you put a research plan + MSc and BSc certificates. 4) "Knowledge of a national language is required" - how strict is this? 3) It really depends on the group. I would suggest you try and just say that you are willing to learn German or take an intensive course before your start. You don't need it to work at WSL but they do so much applied work that it is important when talking to managers/the press etc 4) It typically isn't required but it will likely be a disadvantage as the institute has an increasing emphasis on interaction with stakeholders and management.

column10: Community College. Principal responsibilities include instruction in Foundations of Biology-Evolution, Biodiversity, and Organismal Biology (BIO202). Dig a little digging and I think with a PhD you'd start at Class VI (101k).

Focus can be cell biology, plant biology, mammalogy, ornithology, herpetology, or anatomy and physiology and/or complements the expertise of current faculty in the department. Teaching load is 12 credit hours per semester (lectures count for 3 cr., labs for 1.5 cr.) with teaching responsibilities generally split between service courses (introductory majors or non-majors bio; a&p) and courses within faculty specialty. Small class sizes, reasonable expectations for tenure (minimum 1 peer-reviewed publication + strong teaching evaluations + service). Located in Florence/Muscle Shoals, AL - Low cost of living area roughly 2 hrs south of Nashville and 1 hour west of Huntsville, AL. Currently reviewing and will remain open until filled.

column10: Most PI hires at SERC are in specific fields, but this one is much more general and anyone with an interest in working at SERC is encouraged to apply. It's a fulltime federally-funded research position with no teaching. USAJOBS does not require a cover letter or research statement, but if you wish to include these, they can be appended to your CV and uploaded as a single document, or uploaded as additional, ‘supporting documents’. 1) I've previously done research at SERC and have nothing but wonderful things to say about the people who work there and the facilities. Highly recommend applying to this position. 2) second that, great place with awesome people doing cool and very relevant research. 3) does anyone know if this is capped at a 13 or is there mobility towards a 15 like other federal positions? 4) Is remote work possible? 5) @4 no. And I checked 13 is the top potential. 6) SERC PI here: all SERC PI positions have GS15 promotion potential, and remote work can be done at max 2 days/week (and yes, SERC is a GREAT place to work :-)) 7) if you are applying to a Federal research position I extremeley recommend applying with a cover letter and federal resume version of your CV (am a PhD researcher with Feds) 8) Any explanation of what "You qualify for this position if you possess one year of specialized experience equivalent to at least the GS-12 level in the federal service or comparable pay band system" means? I read this as requiring at least a year at a government job--am I wrong? 9) This i a very helpful resource for applying to this type of job:  https://jabberwocky.weecology.org/2021/06/14/usajobs-guide/ 10) @8 Postdocs are eligible, you don't need to have had a year at a government job. What you do need to do is make sure your cv explicitly states how the experience you have meets the listed specialized experience (usually things like getting grants, publishing, leading projects, etc) x2 ; 11) This website (linked within the job ad) has lots of great tips on applying for federal jobs: https://serc.si.edu/careers/tips-applying-federal-jobs (I'm a current SERC PI and SERC is an awesome place to work! You should apply!) 12) @8 typically postdocs are GS-11 or GS-12 in the fed govt., however I was hired as a GS-12 and applied when I was ABD. It's really a matter of how you describe your responsibilities in your federal resume. A postdoc w. 1 yr + experience should have done all the things asked for as a GS-12. I recommend almost repeating verbatim the quals in the job application on your federal resume. 13) From my understanding, this position is not a direct hire, which means that SERC has to prefer military veterans over all other applicants-- is this true or no? 14) My understanding from similar searches is that that is only true if there is a veteran who is equally qualiifed as everyone else. Someone who doesn't meet the specialized experience won't get jumped to the top of the list. 15) This is exactly right. Qualified vets (or those with other preference statuses) will be ranked higher than those without but they must be qualified. However, because it is not under the direct hire authority only the top X applicants will be referred on to the search committee. In a direct hire search the committee gets to see all qualified applicants. 16) Will this hire proceed or is it disrupted by the federal hiring freeze? x2 17) I don't know, but the URL is gone, so I would say yes its disrupted. 18) Is it not gone just because the deadline is past? There are still active postings listed on the website for positions that are not at the deadline yet. Just hoping it's not impacted! 19) The link from this page gives an error, but it still appears on the USAJobs site (at least under my applications) 20) I heard from a colleague who applied for this position that they received an email that the post was no longer externally advertised given the hiring freeze 21) @20 Interesting, I never received that email like that and I'm an external candidate. x5 22) Has anyone heard anything about this job (02/06)? 23) email 02/05 saying there is a hiring freeze and position is canceled 24) @ 22 nope and I am internal. column10: 1) Never seen a combined department of bio and chem, any thoughts on this type of department? Seems very broad 2) TMU (formerly Ryerson) hasn't historically had a very large or renowned bio program. Which is not to knock it or to say anything about the opportunity, the Chem+Bio pairing likely reflects their general life sciences approach and saving on adminsitrative costs for two small seperate units. 3) Don't know anything about the department, but am from Toronto. For outsiders, this is not an especially research intensive university, which may also be why the departments are combined. The ad sounds like they are interested in research though, so maybe their plan is to improve. 4) I did my master's at TMU in this department...and the department sucked. the chemists judge the biologists on productivity. it's frustrating as hell. do not recommend. it did get me a stepping step to where I wanted to be, but I have a hard time recommending it. 5) I am an existing faculty member at TMU Chem/Bio. The department combo is actually great allowing a biologist to closely collaborate with chemists without taking on that expertise. It does save admin costs - which in an environment where many universities are on the edge of bankruptcy in Ontario (eg. Queens), is an advantage. Our house has a balanced budget and a safe pension fund. We are overshadowed by our larger neighbour U of T's reputation but the department is also relatively young and we have a path maker attitude - we're looking for other folks like us. We are considered a comprehensive university (not just research intensive, not just undergrad education) and our classes and research groups reflect that, with upper level or grad classes having research aspects and research groups including all levels of students. We have many faculty with over $1M grants, which is considerable in Canada. With concerted education efforts for faculty, I think the dynamics of chemists and biologists have improved since the #4 commenter's Masters. The ecologists in the department are uber excited about these positions and are really excited to find our next colleagues. 6) I recently completed a grad degree in this dept. and I strongly suggest that interested applicants look up the research of its current biology faculty rather than relying on outdated comments. It's now the 3rd largest university in the province and things have changed a lot in the past 10 years. 7) I heard that quite a few good people left the department because the university doesn't want teaching stream faculty. bummer. 8) No update 02/16 x1 9) No update 02/25 X4 10)long list interview 03/08 X2 11) long-list interview 03/21 12) I was long-listed, but I didn't hear when they said short list would be emailed. Open call, assessment based on research and teaching expertise. No Swedish requirement at the time of hire. 1) Anyone able to clarify the position title here? Is this equivalent to a US Associate Professor? 2) Here the Swedish title (UL) should be roughly equivalent to a US Associate Professor or a UK Senior Lecturer. It's a permanent post. One level up from Assistant Professor (BUL in Swedish). 3) Does this mean that this is not a tenure-track asisstant professor search? So you can't apply unless you are already TT or tenured? 2) Looking at shortlists from recent calls at the same level, the same department, candidates are either TT or at least hold national/ERC starting grants. Might come down to competitiveness. NOTE: Need to speak Swedish for this job! No, you do not need to speak swedish... 4) @3 to clarify, anyone with the required qualifications can apply. You do not need to be TT or have a big grant. 5) To clarify further, does that mean you'd seriously consider a postdoc applicant? 4 again) FYI I'm not from the institution just have experience in Sweden. They're strictly bound to the requirements detailed in the job ad and it's not uncommon to go straight from PD to Associate if you're competitive. Assistant prof positions aren't as common. 6) note that in Sweden the difference between researcher (extended postdoc) and associate professor is usually pedogogic coursework. These are usually internal promotions without "tenure" and are referred to as docents. You can also become an associate professor with tenure by "winning" an external, competitive and internationally reviewed job search to be a BUL (assistant senior lecturer=assistant professor), then taking coursework to become a Docent ("Assoc professor") and meeting teaching and grantwinning expectations and being promoted to a senior lecturer with tenure (UL; associate professor in the US). Sometimes, like this, associate senior lecturers with "tenure" are hired like this, but I have never known someone without an established research program and grants get one. 7) 5/15/2025 invited to an on campus interview.

No research expectations, "instructionally focused". 1) Surprising teaching combination of 'Biology of Plants (Intro Course)', 'Plant Systematics'  with 'Invertebrate Zoology'. Documented ability to teach in Swedish or English is a requirement unless special reasons prevail. 2) Link here is wrong, don't need to know Swedish to teach in Arkansas 3) correction: the link is not wrong, but the post from above was used for the language requirement. 3) 1/7/25 - applied a few weeks ago, got an email today letting me know that the original job ad was incorrect and this is NOT tenure track. They requested my reply to indicate if I still wanted my materials to be reviewed for the updated job posting. 4) zoom interview invite extended 2/4

A transcript will not be considered “official” if a designation of “Issued to Student” is visible." Glad to see a Dept Chair hire also needs transcript but I suppose it's because someone forgot to delete it! (2) Does anyone know if this is internal? I heard through the grapevine  that UF chair searches are almost always internal. (3) @2, this is a genuinely open search in a great department--the long-serving chair is stepping down to retire. (3) General note. In EE and general Biology Department the Chair almost always serves from the existing faculty, and these are often shorter term 3-6 year positions. Sometimes there are no available or willing internal candidates and an external search can get approved. Very different story in Med schools from what I understand where pretty much every Chair position is external and a long-term semi permanent position. 4) UF, at least CALS/IFAS, does a lot of external searches and hires for chair positions. 5) Can confirm there are no internal candidates at this point!

column10: 1) Job is focusing on butterflies and bee species, but are open to other insect species. Fargo, ND is a relatively good town to live. The research group advertising is a good group to work with and open to many project ideas

Why is this not a TT position?? It sounds like all the responsibility of TT but no stability. 1) Chill out. It's not so different from a soft money position. If you're not in the market for that and are only interested in a TT job, that's totally fine, just don't apply. But there's nothing inherently exploitative or otherwise problematic about soft money positions, and there's nothing inherently exploitative or otherwise problematic about this job either. 2) based response right there. i like it 3) It sure sounds pretty different from most soft money positions. This isn't a case of someone funding their own position through a grant. It sounds like they want someone to come in, start a research program, teach two upper level classes, but have no guarantee that the job will last more than two years. If there is a department need for those two classes and a research program in this area, then a job like this is absolutely cutting into what could otherwise be a permanent position. 4) If you're interested, reach out and ask about the situation - they could just be in a weird unversity budget space where they can't hire TT right now but plan on converting it later. 5) It is a teaching position with low teaching load, and a lot of flexibility to do research. 6)and not have to worry about TT BS. 7) This department has a lot of hiring this year in similar areas. Could be that they're wanting a fixed-term person to cover courses until the TT people get through their teaching releases. 8) MSU person here but not from this dept. We have a lot of fixed term folks here whose role is mainly teaching but do a lot of independent and collaborative research. Some of them have been here for decades, and there is career progression from assistant to associate then to full professor. These are usually not soft money positions, but hard money positions which focus on teaching large undergraduate classes. x2 9) review date online says 12/1?  10) 12/1/26 is the ultimate closing date (just for HR purposes) 11) sorry if this is a stupid question but would non-genetic ornithology focuses be considered? 12) @11, it does say that you need to teach genetics. 13) Zoom interview invitation 1/15. 14) Anyone invited to campus interview yet? 15) Campus interviews began March 12

Located in Juneau, teaching ecology: "To thrive in this role, the successful candidate will have demonstrated experience in geospatial data analysis with regard to forest ecosystems and the ability to teach introductory forest ecology and upper division courses that support degrees in Environmental Science, Environmental Resources, and Biology"; 1) A bit odd funding; 3y of 9mo/y and then become 5-6 mo with remainder grant-based. Never seen that before. 2) If you've never been to Juneau or spent time in SE Alaska, make sure you can handle the weather. It is a rainforest and Juneau gets more than double the rain that Seattle gets per year. The city is small but there is a ton of natural beauty (there is a glacier in town), it is just isolated-- there are no roads in/out and you have to fly pretty much everywhere. 3) *quickly retreating glacier. I've lived in Juneau most of my life and the rain and the winter dark (mid Dec has ~6 hours of light during the day) tend to be hard to adjust to. But amazing, artsy community I love living in! 4) Rejection receieved 2/10 5) First round Zoom interview 2/5

column10: Review date posted as 11/30 but job only made available 11/20, and search committee hasn't started reviewing yet, so please still apply. There is also a similar Anat/Phys position posted in the same dept. SC Update: we'll be reviewing starting in the new year so plenty of time to apply! We have really great teaching faculty and dept interest/support for CUREs. 1) Would there be opportunities for research loading, for instance 80% teaching, 10% service, 10% research?  2) It would probably be easy to find collaborations, but the teaching load is likely to not change unless you have a grant for a buyout.  If you do have research funds for a buyout the process is simple so long as someone is available to teach. 3) Does anyone know exactly what the teaching load is? 4) SC- Teaching workload is roughly a 3:3 but can count differently with lab coordination and can include multiple sections of same course. You can oversee student individualized instruction (UG research) for some teaching hours per semester. 4) @1 - a 10% research allocation sounds like a potential quagmire to me and a good way to burn out. If you are 80% teaching, what counts as 10% research? If you meet with students, do experiments, field work, and write papers, you will always be going over 4 hours a week. And teaching is locked in in terms of effort. So you would have a job that your are working well over 100% capacity all the time. 4) 1 again-- All good points from #4!! I suppose I was mainly asking if research could/would be part of the job description. If research is in the job description, then there is at least a recognition from the admin that you will indeed be doing research. If its not in the job description, then admin will wonder why you are spending any time on research... Also, 10% load for research is quite common at regional PUIs-- there is a reseach expectation, but you are not expected (or encouraged) to always be meeting with students, doing experiments, field work, and writing papers. Instead, you mgiht be expected to spend 4 hours per week writing that manuscript that you started a couple of years ago, or you might spend four hours per week meeting with your one UG students. The point is that explictly having research in your job description enables you to do low-intensity research of some kind, with some support from your institution. If research is not part of your job description, you might not have any research support from your institution... TLDR: If you want to do any research, you need research in your job description. 5) SC again to just clarify - as advertised, this is a teaching track position and is a teaching/service split. While there are opportunities to incorporate research through your teaching methodologies and collaborations with research-track faculty, and many teaching faculty do so in some capacity, you would not be annually evaluated on research as the position is advertised. Our workload is a bit in flux as we accommodate system level changes, so it is hard to say definitively what is possible though. 6) Anybody know what the salary range might be? 7) @6 This is a public university, and you can look up Assistant professor salaries 8) Any updates? 9) SC has decided short list and is sending/has sent zoom invites 10) finaly received a rejection... 11) Has anyone gotten an offer?  12) Any updates?
